ovdesc.p: Overview A NDF is a product where one of the currencies is unable to be settled. Because of this the deal must be fixed at a time and from a rate source arranged at the time of the original trade. When the rate is fixed on the fixing date the settlement will be a net settlement in the deliverable currency only, calculated by using the difference between the original Foreign exchange rate and the fixing rate. There are 2 types of NDF transactions to take into account: Vanilla this is a standard NDF transaction type, which has a rate fixing of 2 working days before settlement date no exceptions. Exotic which is based on the Vanilla NDF, with a variation that allows the fixing date to be set at any date during the life of the transaction. If a NDF is fixed early, then a discount to the profit is taken by the bank. This discount amount needs to be amortised. Settlement date remains the same and is unchanged.

Identifies each NDF transaction. The Reference Number will be shown on all output generated from the transaction and will be generated automatically when specified as such in the Company table for the NDF Application. Otherwise, it will need to be entered for each transaction and subsequently checked by the System for uniqueness. To avoid the necessity to input the complete Reference Number, the User has the facility to input only the sequence number of the transaction to access any transaction which has been input that day. The Application will automatically generate the seven first digits and append them to the front of the sequence number in order to retrieve the requested transaction. Access to any NDF transaction from a previous day requires the input of the corresponding julian day and the year if the contract has been done in a previous year. The reference number has the following format NDYYDDDNNNNN where: ND = Application indicator for the NDF Application. YY = The last two digits of the year when the transaction is processed DDD = Julian day number within year when the NDF is processed. NNNNN = Five digit sequential number. The above numbering convention enables 99,999 deals to be struck on any one day. Thus : ND8530500010 is the 10th NDF transaction of the 2nd of November 1985, i.e: . ND = NDF Application Id. . 85 = Year 1985 . 305 = 2nd of November (305th day 1985) . 00010 = 10th transaction on that day.

10 numeric characters, prefixed by ND: NDyydddnnnnn ND followed by 10 numbers (see Details) (Mandatory input) If the Reference Number is entered, during initial input, it will be validated for uniqueness. When input, this field will only be allowed in the format specified above.

This field is automatically populated by the system on committing the NDF contract. This common reference will be used on all messages transmitted through SWIFT.

The common reference consists of the SWIFT confirmation address codes of the two counterparties, i.e. ourselves and the CPARTY of the transaction. These codes will appear in alphabetical order. From the CPARTY SWIFT confirmation address specified in the Agency file, the system will automatically select the first four digits plus the seventh and eighth digit.

The two codes are separated by four figures from the notional rate(fixed rate after deal fixing) on the contract as agreed by the two counterparties. The notional /fixed rate itself is expressed in the following form:
Rate Shown as

Thus for a NDF deal between ourselves with SWIFT confirmation address XXXXXX and a CPARTY with SWIFT address ABCAZACP at notional rate of 1.855129400 , say, then the Swift Common Reference should be constructed as follows:
ABCACP1294XXXXXX
The system will then display the above reference at this field and it would be used on all SWIFT message types relating to this contract and on all the entries generated by Accounting.
A six digit code followed by notional/fixed rate followed by another six digit code. Type SS characters.

All Trades should have a Unique Transaction Identifier (UTI) which is generated, communicated and matched
Determination of who generates the UTI should follow the existing industry best practices for that Asset class

The UTI.USI.API attached in OC.PARAMETER and invoked during NDF deal capture determines who is the party responsible for UTI generation and does the following. • If a value is present during deal capture the API is not invoked, on the assumption that the UTI is generated and supplied by the other Counterparty. • If no value is present during the deal capture, the API is invoked to determine the party responsible for generating the UTI. If the Other counterparty is responsible, still an UTI is generated with a suffix as TEMP to show that the UTI from the other counterparty is awaited and in the meantime, the reporting is done with a Temporary ID. If T24 Bank is responsible for UTI generation, then the same is generated without TEMP. • Where a reporting has been made with UTI having TEMP as suffix and subsequently the Counterparty supplies the UTI, the following procedure has to be followed to ensure reporting with actual UTI. • The field Action Type needs to be changed to ‘E’ and record to be authorized. Later, the UTI field should be modified with the actual UTI received. Set the Action Type field to ‘N’ and authorize the record. In this way, the previous reporting gets cancelled and the new reporting goes with correct UTI.
Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed

Under the Regulatory Reporting to a Trade Repository, it is not only the initial trade that is reported but also the life cycle events of the Trade that follow. A change in the action type is indicative of an event on the contract and requires to be reported. Change in Action Types is allowed both manually and automatically.
Specifies the ACTION.TYPE that is populated based on the event on trade
Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed
Allowed optional values are N, M, E, C, Z and O
N denotes that the ACTION.TYPE is NEW. Value of 'N' is defaulted for a new contract. User is also allowed to change the status to N if the previous status is E.

E denotes that the ACTION.TYPE is REVERSE or Correction. In case of wrongly entered UTI values or a Temporary UTI was used previously, the old UTI should be reported with ACTION.TYPE as 'E' for error reporting first and then change the Action Type to NEW after keying in the actual UTI. This way the previous reporting with temporary UTI is replaced by the one with final UTI. Action Type ‘E’ is also used to undo the reporting of a particular transaction done which should not have been done reported at all in the first instance.
M denotes that the ACTION.TYPE is MODIFIED. In case of change in the RATE.FIXING.DATE the ACTION.TYPE is set to 'M'

C denotes that the ACTION.TYPE is CANCELLED.In case of any change in maturity/value date i.e. early termination of the contract should be reported with C.In NDF this MATURITY.DATE field is No change field. So ACTION.TYPE never gets populated automatically with type as C but It can be manually updated as ‘c’ and the contract can be cancelled.
Z denotes Compression update. This means the trade being reported is generated out of a compression activity.
O denotes OTHER types. When OTHER is used, additional information as to what OTHER mean should be mentioned separately.

Denotes the OC Clearing Status.
Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed
Allowed optional values are Bilateral, Submitted, Accepted, Rejected, Cleared and Terminated.
BILATERAL - when a fresh contract is inputted this field should be updated as BILATERAL

SUBMITTED - when the inputted contract is submitted to Trade Repository it should get updated as SUBMITTED.
The previous clearing status of the contract should be BILATERAL
when OC.CLG.STATUS of the contract is SUBMITTED both CLG.MEM.ID and CENTRAl.CLG.PARTY fields cannot be NULL

ACCEPTED - when the contract is accepted by the Trade Repository it should get updated as ACCEPTED.
The previous status should be SUBMITTED

REJECTED - when the contract is rejected by the Trade Repository it should get updated as REJECTED.
The previous status should be SUBMITTED

CLEARED - When the status of the contract is ACCEPTED, User is expected to reverse the contract and enter a new one with Trade status as CLEARED
when the status is CLEARED fields like CENTRAL.CLG.PARTY, CLG.MEM.ID, BILATERAL.REF are mandatory

Terminated - A cleared contract when cancelled/terminated by the Trade Repository should be updated as TERMINATED.
The previous status should be CLEARED
This is a no change field

1.Allows particular groups of contracts to be identified.
2.The conditions which determine a particular CONTRACT.GRP code are defined in the ND.DEAL record of the APPL.GEN.CONDITION application

3.Each time the contract is changed the conditions will be re-evaluated which can result in a new CONTRACT.GRP code. If the CONTRACT.GRP value changes then this can result in a new FTT.TAX.TYPE.KEY being allocated depending on the set up of the relevant TAX.TYPE.CONDITION record.However, the conditions will not re-evaluated after authorization.
5 character alphanumeric
Using this field together with the CONTRACT.GRP field it is possible to determine a particular tax code from conditions based on
a. General tax type as defined in the TAX.TYPE.CONDITION application
b. Type of customer as defined in the CUSTOMER.CHARGES application
c. Type of contract as defined in the CONTRACT.GRP field.
The value in this field must equate to a record in the TAX.TYPE.CONDITION application which contains tax codes related to customer tax group and contract group.
Whenever tax is to be recalculated the correct tax code will be determined and the Tax related fields gets updated accordingly.
Optional input, must be present as a record on TAX.TYPE.CONDITION. The actual TAX.TYPE.CONDITION key value will be prefixed by the "*" character (asterisk).

Identifies the Tax Amount calculated in EUR, which is the Tax payable currency under EUFTT. The notional conversion between the FTT.TAX.BASE.CCY and EUR is based on mid-reval rate in currency record.
Value populated in FTT.TAX.AMT.BASE is converted to EUR.
No input field.

Local equivalent of Financial Transaction Tax amount. Where the Tax currency and PL currency are different, using Mid-reval rate from the tax currency record, the LCY equivalent is calculated and accounting entries are based on this value.
No input field.

Provides the option to T24 bank to collect the Financial Transaction Tax payable by the Counterparty also. If yes, accounting entries are raised to collect counterparty’s tax wherein customer Account is debited and Tax suspense Account is credited. The values No or Null means T24 bank does not collect the FTT payable by the counterparty or in other words the counterparty himself remits the FTT. This option is provided on the premise that where the counterparty is a customer of the bank ( not an interbank counterparty) the T24 bank assumes responsibility to collect and pay the FTT payable by the customer
Values allowed are Yes, No or Null.
Default value will be from ND.PARAMETER but can be overridden by the User.
